etymologies: late 16th century: from Latin reciprocus (based on re- ‘back’ + pro- ‘forward’) + -al

definitions: given, felt, or done in return

examples.text: she was hoping for some reciprocal comment or gesture

shortDefinitions: given, felt, or done in return

definitions: (of an agreement or obligation) bearing on or binding each of two parties equally

examples.text: the treaty is a bilateral commitment with reciprocal rights and duties

shortDefinitions: bearing on or binding each of two parties equally

definitions: (of a pronoun or verb) expressing mutual action or relationship.
shortDefinitions: (of pronoun or verb) expressing mutual action or relationship

definitions: (of a course or bearing) differing from a given course or bearing by 180 degrees

examples.text: he took up a reciprocal heading and dropped down to 2,000 ft

shortDefinitions: (of course or bearing) differing from given course or bearing by 180 degrees

definitions: (of a quantity or function) related to another so that their product is one.
shortDefinitions: (of quantity or function) related to another so that their product is unity

definitions: a mathematical expression or function so related to another that their product is one; the quantity obtained by dividing the number one by a given quantity

examples.text: the compressibility is the reciprocal of the bulk modulus

shortDefinitions: expression or function so related to another that their product is unity

definitions: a pronoun or verb expressing mutual action or relationship, e.g. each other, fight.
shortDefinitions: pronoun or verb expressing mutual action or relationship
